sourceDesc.p: A modernized text of Famous Victories of Henry the Fifth: Containing the Honourable Battell of Agincourt, Quarto version, 1598. Edition first published on the ISE platform. Converted, remediated, and republished on the LEMDO platform in the QME anthology.

persName.name: Prince Henry, Henry IV’s son and later Henry V
Jockey (Sir John Oldcastle), Prince Henry’s companion
Two Receivers, Henry IV’s tax and rent collectors
John Cobbler, a cobbler and member of the parish watch
Robin Pewterer, a pewterer and member of the parish watch
Lawrence Costermonger, a fruit-seller and member of the parish watch
Derrick, a carrier and later John Cobbler’s apprentice
Earl of Oxford, one of Henry IV’s lords
Earl of Exeter, one of Henry IV’s lords
Duke of York, Henry V’s uncle
Archbishop of Bruges, the French ambassador
Duke of Burgundy, Charles VI’s most powerful noble

div.stage: Enter the young Prince Henry, Ned, and Tom.

sp.speaker: Prince Henry
sp.p: Come away, Ned and Tom!

sp.speaker: Ned and Tom
sp.p: Here, my lord.

sp.speaker: Prince Henry
sp.p: Come away, my lads. Tell me, sirs, how much gold have you got?

sp.speaker: Ned
sp.p: Faith, my lord, I have got five hundred pound.

sp.speaker: Prince Henry
sp.p: But tell me, Tom, how much hast thou got?

sp.speaker: Tom
sp.p: Faith, my lord, some four hundred pound.

sp.speaker: Prince Henry
sp.p: Four hundred pounds? Bravely spoken, lads! But tell me, sirs, think you not that it was a villainous part of me to rob my father’s receivers?

sp.speaker: Ned
sp.p: Why no, my lord. It was but a trick of youth.

sp.speaker: Prince Henry
sp.p: Faith, Ned, thou sayest true. But tell me, sirs, whereabouts are we?

sp.speaker: Tom
sp.p: My lord, we are now about a mile off London.

sp.speaker: Prince Henry
sp.p:
But, sirs, I marvel that Sir John Oldcastle comes not away. Zounds, see where he comes!
Enter Jockey Sir John Oldcastle.
How now, Jockey, what news with thee?

sp.speaker: Jockey
sp.p: Faith, my lord, such news as passeth, for the town of Deptford is risen with hue and cry after your man which parted from us the last night and has set upon and hath robbed a poor carrier.

sp.speaker: Prince Henry
sp.p: Zounds, the villain that was wont to spy out our booties?

sp.speaker: Jockey
sp.p: Ay, my lord, even the very same.

sp.speaker: Prince Henry
sp.p: Now, base-minded rascal, to rob a poor carrier! Well, it skills not. I’ll save the base villain’s life. Ay, I may. But tell me, Jockey, whereabouts be the receivers?

sp.speaker: Jockey
sp.p: Faith, my lord, they are hard by, but the best is, we are a-horseback and they be afoot, so we may escape them.

sp.speaker: Prince Henry
sp.p: Well, if the villains come, let me alone with them. But tell me, Jockey, how much got’st thou from the knaves? For I am sure I got something, for one of the villains so belammed me about the shoulders as I shall feel it this month.

sp.speaker: Jockey
sp.p: Faith, my lord, I have got a hundred pound.

sp.speaker: Prince Henry
sp.p: A hundred pound! Now, bravely spoken, Jockey. But come, sirs, lay all your money before me. They place their booty at his feet. Now, by heaven, here is a brave show! But, as I am true gentleman, I will have the half of this spent tonight. But, sirs, take up your bags. Here come the receivers. Let me alone.

sp.speaker: 1 Receiver
sp.p: Alas, good fellow, what shall we do? I dare never go home to the court, for I shall be hanged. But look, here is the young prince. What shall we do?

sp.speaker: Prince Henry
sp.p: How now, you villains, what are you?

sp.speaker: 1 Receiver
sp.p: Aside to 2 Receiver Speak you to him.

sp.speaker: 2 Receiver
sp.p: Replying aside No, I pray, speak you to him.

sp.speaker: Prince Henry
sp.p: Why, how now you rascals, why speak you not?

sp.speaker: 1 Receiver
sp.p: Forsooth we be — Aside to 2 Receiver pray speak you to him.

sp.speaker: Prince Henry
sp.p: Zounds, villains, speak, or I’ll cut off your heads.

sp.speaker: 2 Receiver
sp.p: To Prince Henry Forsooth, he can tell the tale better than I.

sp.speaker: 1 Receiver
sp.p: Forsooth, we be your father’s receivers.

sp.speaker: Prince Henry
sp.p: Are you my father’s receivers? Then I hope ye have brought me some money.

sp.speaker: 1 Receiver
sp.p: Money? Alas, sir, we be robbed.

sp.speaker: Prince Henry
sp.p: Robbed? How many were there of them?

sp.speaker: 1 Receiver
sp.p: Marry, sir, there were four of them, and one of them had Sir John Oldcastle’s bay hobby and your black nag.

sp.speaker: Prince Henry
sp.p: Gog’s wounds! To Jockey How like you this, Jockey? To the Receivers Blood, you villains! My father robbed of his money abroad, and we robbed in our stables. But tell me, how many were of them?

sp.speaker: 1 Receiver
sp.p: If it please you, there were four of them, and there was one about the bigness of you, but I am sure I so belammed him about the shoulders that he will feel it this month.

sp.speaker: Prince Henry
sp.p: Gog’s wounds, you lammed them fairly — so that they have carried away your money! To Ned, Tom, and Jockey But come, sirs, what shall we do with the villains?

sp.speaker: Receivers
sp.p: I beseech your grace, be good to us.

sp.speaker: Ned
sp.p: I pray you, my lord, forgive them this once.
Well, stand up and get you gone. And look that you speak not a word of it, for if there be, zounds, I’ll hang you and all your kin.

sp.speaker: Prince Henry
sp.p: Now, sirs, how like you this? Was not this bravely done? For now the villains dare not speak a word of it, I have so feared them with words. Now, whither shall we go?

sp.speaker: Ned, Tom, and Jockey
sp.p: Why, my lord, you know our old hostess at Feversham?

sp.speaker: Prince Henry
sp.p: Our hostess at Feversham? Blood, what shall we do there? We have a thousand pound about us, and we shall go to a petty alehouse? No, no. You know the old tavern in Eastcheap? There is good wine. Besides, there is a pretty wench that can talk well, for I delight as much in their tongues as any part about them.

sp.speaker: Ned, Tom, and Jockey
sp.p: We are ready to wait upon your grace.

sp.speaker: Prince Henry
sp.p: Gog’s wounds! Wait? We will go all together. We are all fellows, I tell you, sirs. An the king my father were dead, we would be all kings. Therefore, come away.

sp.speaker: Ned
sp.p: Gog’s wounds, bravely spoken, Harry!

div.stage: Exeunt Prince Henry, Ned, Tom, and Jockey.
Enter John Cobbler, Robin Pewterer, Lawrence Costermonger.

sp.speaker: John
sp.p: All is well here, all is well, masters.

sp.speaker: Robin
sp.p: How say you, neighbor John Cobbler?
I think it best that my neighbor, Robin Pewterer, went to Pudding Lane end, and we will watch here at Billingsgate Ward. How say you, neighbor Robin, how like you this?

sp.speaker: Robin
sp.p: Marry, well, neighbors. I care not much if I go to Pudding Lane’s end. But, neighbors, an you hear any ado about me, make haste. And if I hear any ado about you, I will come to you.

sp.speaker: Lawrence
sp.p: Neighbor, what news hear you of the young prince?

sp.speaker: John
sp.p: Marry, neighbor, I hear say he is a toward young prince, for if he meet any by the highway, he will not let to talk with him. I dare not call him thief, but sure he is one of these taking fellows.

sp.speaker: Lawrence
sp.p: Indeed, neighbor, I hear say he is as lively a young prince as ever was.

sp.speaker: John
sp.p: Ay, and I hear say, if he use it long, his father will cut him off from the crown. But, neighbor, say nothing of that.

sp.speaker: Lawrence
sp.p: No, no, neighbor, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: John
sp.p: Neighbor, methinks you begin to sleep. If you will, we will sit down, for I think it is about midnight.

sp.speaker: Lawrence
sp.p: Marry, content, neighbor, let us sleep.

stage.supplied: John and Lawrence lie down and sleep.

sp.speaker: Derrick
sp.p: Whoa! whoa there! whoa there!

sp.speaker: Robin
sp.p: O neighbors, what mean you to sleep, and such ado in the streets?

sp.speaker: John and Lawrence
sp.p: How now, neighbor, what’s the matter?

sp.speaker: Derrick
sp.p: Whoa there! whoa there! whoa there!

sp.speaker: John
sp.p: Why, what ail’st thou? Here is no horses.

sp.speaker: Derrick
sp.p: Oh, alas, man, I am robbed! Whoa there, whoa there!

sp.speaker: Robin
sp.p: Hold him, neighbor Cobbler.

sp.speaker: John
sp.p: Why, I see thou art a plain clown.

sp.speaker: Derrick
sp.p: Am I a clown? Zounds, masters, do clowns go in silk apparel? I am sure all we gentlemen clowns in Kent scant go so well. Zounds, you know clowns very well. To John Hear you, are you Master Constable? An you be, speak, for I will not take it at his Derrick points to Robin hands.

sp.speaker: John
sp.p: Faith, I am not Master Constable, but I am one of his bade officers, for he is not here.

sp.speaker: Derrick
sp.p: Is not Master Constable here? Well, it is no matter. I’ll have the law at his hands.

sp.speaker: John
sp.p: Nay, I pray you, do not take the law of us.

sp.speaker: Derrick
sp.p: Well, you are one of his beastly officers.

sp.speaker: John
sp.p: I am one of his bade officers.

sp.speaker: Derrick
sp.p: Why, then, I charge thee look to him.

sp.speaker: John
sp.p: Nay, but hear ye, sir. You seem to be an honest fellow, and we are poor men, and now ’tis night, and we would be loth to have anything ado. Therefore, I pray thee, put it up.

sp.speaker: Derrick
sp.p: First, thou sayest true, I am an honest fellow—and a proper, handsome fellow too—and you seem to be poor men. Therefore I care not greatly; nay, I am quickly pacified. But, an you chance to spy the thief, I pray you lay hold on him.

sp.speaker: Robin
sp.p: Yes, that we will, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Derrick
sp.p: Aside ’Tis a wonderful thing to see how glad the knave is, now I have forgiven him.

sp.speaker: John
sp.p: To Lawrence and Robin Neighbors, do ye look about you. How now, who’s there?

sp.speaker: Cutbert Cutter
sp.p: Here is a good fellow. I pray you, which is the way to the old tavern in Eastcheap?

sp.speaker: Derrick
sp.p: Whoop hollo! Now, Gadshill, knowest thou me?

sp.speaker: Cutbert Cutter
sp.p: I know thee for an ass.

sp.speaker: Derrick
sp.p: And I know thee for a taking fellow, upon Gad’s Hill in Kent. A bots light upon ye!

sp.speaker: Cutbert Cutter
sp.p: The whoreson villain would be knocked!

sp.speaker: Derrick
sp.p: Masters — villain! — an ye be men, stand to him and take his weapon from him. Let him not pass you.

sp.speaker: John
sp.p: My friend, what make you abroad now? It is too late to walk now.

sp.speaker: Cutbert Cutter
sp.p: It is not too late for true men to walk.

sp.speaker: Lawrence
sp.p: We know thee not to be a true man.

stage.supplied: John, Robin, and Lawrence seize Cutbert.

sp.speaker: Cutbert Cutter
sp.p: Why, what do you mean to do with me? Zounds, I am one of the king’s liege people.

sp.speaker: Derrick
sp.p: Hear you, sir, are you one of the king’s liege people?

sp.speaker: Cutbert Cutter
sp.p: Ay, marry, am I, sir. What say you to it?

sp.speaker: Derrick
sp.p: Marry, sir, I say you are one of the king’s filching people.

sp.speaker: John
sp.p: Come, come, let’s have him away.

sp.speaker: Cutbert Cutter
sp.p: Why, what have I done?

sp.speaker: Robin
sp.p: Thou hast robbed a poor fellow and taken away his goods from him.

sp.speaker: Cutbert Cutter
sp.p: I never saw him before.

sp.speaker: Derrick
sp.p: Masters, who comes here?

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: How now, Goodman Cobbler?

sp.speaker: John
sp.p: How now, Robert, what makes thou abroad at this time of night?

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: Marry, I have been at the Counter. I can tell such news as never you have heard the like.

sp.speaker: John
sp.p: What is that, Robert? What is the matter?

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: Why, this night about two hours ago, there came the young prince and three or four more of his companions and called for wine good store, and then they sent for a noise of musicians and were very merry for the space of an hour. Then, whether their music liked them not or whether they had drunk too much wine or no, I cannot tell, but our pots flew against the walls, and then they drew their swords and went into the street and fought, and some took one part and some took another, but for the space of half an hour there was such a bloody fray as passeth, and none could part them until such time as the mayor and sheriff were sent for, and then at the last with much ado they took them, and so the young prince was carried to the Counter. And then about one hour after, there came a messenger from the court in all haste from the king for my lord mayor and the sheriff, but for what cause I know not.

sp.speaker: John
sp.p: Here is news indeed, Robert.

sp.speaker: Lawrence
sp.p: Marry, neighbor, this news is strange indeed. I think it best, neighbor, to rid our hands of this fellow first.

sp.speaker: Cutbert Cutter
sp.p: What mean you to do with me?

sp.speaker: John
sp.p: We mean to carry you to the prison, and there to remain ’til the sessions day.

sp.speaker: Cutbert Cutter
sp.p: Then, I pray you, let me go to the prison where my master is.

sp.speaker: John
sp.p: Nay, thou must go to the country prison, to Newgate. Therefore, come away.

sp.speaker: Cutbert Cutter
sp.p: To Derrick I prithee be good to me, honest fellow.

sp.speaker: Derrick
sp.p: Ay, marry will I, I’ll be very charitable to thee, for I will never leave thee ’til I see thee on the gallows.

div.stage: Enter Henry the Fourth with the Earl of Exeter and the Lord of Oxford.

sp.speaker: Oxford
sp.p: An’t please your majesty, here is my lord mayor and the sheriff of London to speak with your majesty.

sp.speaker: Henry IV
sp.p:
Admit them to our presence.
Enter the Mayor and the Sheriff.
Now, my good lord mayor of London, the cause of my sending for you at this time is to tell you of a matter which I have learned of my council. Herein I understand that you have committed my son to prison without our leave and licence. What, although he be a rude youth and likely to give occasion, yet you might have considered that he is a prince, and my son, and not to be haled to prison by every subject.

sp.speaker: Lord Mayor
sp.p: May it please your majesty to give us leave to tell our tale?

sp.speaker: Henry IV
sp.p: Or else, God forbid, otherwise you might think me an unequal judge, having more affection to my son than to any rightful judgment.

sp.speaker: Lord Mayor
sp.p: Then I do not doubt but we shall rather deserve commendations at your majesty’s hands than any anger.

sp.speaker: Henry IV
sp.p: Go to, say on.

sp.speaker: Lord Mayor
sp.p: Then, if it please your majesty, this night betwixt two and three of the clock in the morning, my lord the young prince with a very disordered company came to the old tavern in Eastcheap, and whether it was that their music liked them not or whether they were overcome with wine, I know not, but they drew their swords, and into the street they went, and some took my lord the young prince’s part and some took the other, but betwixt them there was such a bloody fray for the space of half an hour that neither watchmen nor any other could stay them ’til my brother the sheriff of London and I were sent for, and at the last with much ado we stayed them, but it was long first, which was a great disquieting to all your loving subjects thereabouts. And then, my good lord, we knew not whether your grace had sent them to try us, whether we would do justice, or whether it were of their own voluntary will or not, we cannot tell. And therefore in such a case we knew not what to do, but for our own safeguard we sent him to ward, where he wanteth nothing that is fit for his grace and your majesty’s son. And thus most humbly beseeching your majesty to think of our answer.

sp.speaker: Henry IV
sp.p: Stand aside until we have further deliberated on your answer.

sp.speaker: Henry IV
sp.p: Ah, Harry, Harry, now thrice-accursed Harry, that hath gotten a son which with grief will end his father’s days. O my son, a prince thou art, ay, a prince indeed — and to deserve imprisonment! And well have they done, and like faithful subjects. To Exeter and Oxford Discharge them and let them go.

sp.speaker: Exeter
sp.p: I beseech your grace, be good to my lord the young prince.

sp.speaker: Henry IV
sp.p: Nay, nay, ’tis no matter. Let him alone.

sp.speaker: Oxford
sp.p: Perchance the mayor and the sheriff have been too precise in this matter.

sp.speaker: Henry IV
sp.p: No, they have done like faithful subjects. I will go myself to discharge them and let them go.

div.stage: Enter Lord Chief Justice, Clerk of the Office, Jailor with several Officers, John Cobbler, Derrick, and the Thief Cutbert Cutter.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Justice
sp.p: Jailor, bring the prisoner to the bar.

sp.speaker: Derrick
sp.p: Hear you, my lord, I pray you bring the bar to the prisoner.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Justice
sp.p: Hold thy hand up at the bar.

sp.speaker: Cutbert Cutter
sp.p: Here it is, my lord.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Justice
sp.p: Clerk of the Office, read his indictment.

sp.speaker: Clerk
sp.p: What is thy name?

sp.speaker: Cutbert Cutter
sp.p: My name was known before I came here and shall be when I am gone, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Justice
sp.p: Ay, I think so, but we will know it better before thou go.

sp.speaker: Derrick
sp.p: Zounds, an you do but send to the next jail, we are sure to know his name, for this is not the first prison he hath been in, I’ll warrant you.

sp.speaker: Clerk
sp.p: What is thy name?

sp.speaker: Cutbert Cutter
sp.p: What need you to ask, an have it in writing?

sp.speaker: Clerk
sp.p: Is not thy name Cutbert Cutter?

sp.speaker: Cutbert Cutter
sp.p: What the devil need you ask, an know it so well?

sp.speaker: Clerk
sp.p: Why then, Cutbert Cutter, I indict thee by the name of Cutbert Cutter for robbing a poor carrier the twentieth day of May last past, in the fourteenth year of the reign of our sovereign lord King Henry the Fourth, for setting upon a poor carrier upon Gad’s Hill in Kent, and having beaten and wounded the said carrier, and taken his goods from him.

sp.speaker: Derrick
sp.p: Oh, masters, stay there. Nay, let’s never belie the man, for he hath not beaten and wounded me also, but he hath beaten and wounded my pack and hath taken the great raze of ginger that bouncing Bess with the jolly buttocks should have had. That grieves me most.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Justice
sp.p: Well, what sayest thou? Art thou guilty or not guilty?

sp.speaker: Cutbert Cutter
sp.p: Not guilty, my lord.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Justice
sp.p: By whom wilt thou be tried?

sp.speaker: Cutbert Cutter
sp.p: By my lord the young prince or by myself, whether you will.

div.stage: Enter the young Prince Henry, with Ned and Tom.

sp.speaker: Prince Henry
sp.p: Come away, my lads. To Cutbert Cutter Gog’s wounds, ye villain, what make you here? I must go about my business myself, and you must stand loitering here?

sp.speaker: Cutbert Cutter
sp.p: Why, my lord, they have bound me and will not let me go.

sp.speaker: Prince Henry
sp.p: Have they bound thee, villain? To Lord Chief Justice Why, how now, my lord?

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Justice
sp.p: I am glad to see your grace in good health.

sp.speaker: Prince Henry
sp.p: Why, my lord, this is my man. ’Tis marvel you knew him not long before this. I tell you, he is a man of his hands.

sp.speaker: Cutbert Cutter
sp.p: Ay, Gog’s wounds, that I am. Try me who dare!

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Justice
sp.p: Your grace shall find small credit by acknowledging him to be your man.

sp.speaker: Prince Henry
sp.p: Why, my lord, what hath he done?

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Justice
sp.p: An it please your majesty, he hath robbed a poor carrier.

sp.speaker: Derrick
sp.p: Hear you, sir. Marry, it was one Derrick, Goodman Hobling’s man of Kent.

sp.speaker: Prince Henry
sp.p: What, was’t you, button-breech?— Of my word, my lord, he did it but in jest.

sp.speaker: Derrick
sp.p: Hear you, sir. Is it your man’s quality to rob folks in jest? In faith, he shall be hanged in earnest.

sp.speaker: Prince Henry
sp.p: Well, my lord, what do you mean to do with my man?

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Justice
sp.p: An’t please your grace, the law must pass on him according to justice; then he must be executed.

sp.speaker: Derrick
sp.p: Hear you, sir, I pray you. Is it your man’s quality to rob folks in jest? In faith, he shall be hanged in jest.

sp.speaker: Henry V
sp.p: Well, my lord, what mean you to do with my man?

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Justice
sp.p: An’t please your grace, the law must pass on him according to justice; then he must be executed.

sp.speaker: Prince Henry
sp.p: Why, then, belike you mean to hang my man?

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Justice
sp.p: I am sorry that it falls out so.

sp.speaker: Prince Henry
sp.p: Why, my lord, I pray ye, who am I?

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Justice
sp.p: An’t please your grace, you are my lord the young prince, our king that shall be after the decease of our sovereign lord, King Henry the Fourth, whom God grant long to reign.

sp.speaker: Prince Henry
sp.p: You say true, my lord. And you will hang my man?

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Justice
sp.p: An’t like your grace, I must needs do justice.

sp.speaker: Prince Henry
sp.p: Tell me, my lord, shall I have my man?

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Justice
sp.p: I cannot, my lord.

sp.speaker: Prince Henry
sp.p: But will you not let him go?

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Justice
sp.p: I am sorry that his case is so ill.

sp.speaker: Prince Henry
sp.p: Tush, case me no casings. Shall I have my man?

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Justice
sp.p: I cannot, nor I may not, my lord.

sp.speaker: Prince Henry
sp.p: Nay, and I shall not, say, and then I am answered!

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Justice
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Prince Henry
sp.p: No? Then I will have him.

div.stage: He giveth him a box on the ear.

sp.speaker: Ned
sp.p: Gog’s wounds, my lord, shall I cut off his head?

sp.speaker: Prince Henry
sp.p: No, I charge you, draw not your swords, but get you hence— provide a noise of musicians. Away, begone!

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Justice
sp.p: Well, my lord, I am content to take it at your hands.

sp.speaker: Prince Henry
sp.p: Nay, an you be not, you shall have more.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Justice
sp.p: Why, I pray you, my lord, who am I?

sp.speaker: Prince Henry
sp.p: You? Who knows not you? Why, man, you are Lord Chief Justice of England.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Justice
sp.p: Your grace hath said truth. Therefore in striking me in this place you greatly abuse me, and not me only but also your father, whose lively person here in this place I do represent. And therefore, to teach you what prerogatives mean, I commit you to the Fleet until we have spoken with your father.

sp.speaker: Prince Henry
sp.p: Why, then, belike you mean to send me to the Fleet?

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Justice
sp.p: Ay indeed, and therefore carry him away.

div.stage: Exit Prince Henry with the Officers.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Justice
sp.p: Jailor, carry the prisoner to Newgate again until the next ’ssizes.

sp.speaker: Jailor
sp.p: At your commandment, my lord, it shall be done.

stage.supplied: Exeunt Lord Chief Justice, Clerk of the Office, John Cobbler, Derrick, and Cutbert Cutter with Jailor

sp.speaker: Derrick
sp.p: Zounds, masters, here’s ado, when princes must go to prison! Why, John, didst ever see the like?

sp.speaker: John
sp.p: Oh, Derrick, trust me, I never saw the like.

sp.speaker: Derrick
sp.p: Why, John, thou mayest see what princes be in choler. A judge a box on the ear! I’ll tell thee, John, O John, I would not have done it for twenty shillings.

sp.speaker: John
sp.p: No, nor I. There had been no way but one with us: we should have been hanged.

sp.speaker: Derrick
sp.p: Faith, John, I’ll tell thee what. Thou shalt be my lord chief justice, and thou shalt sit in the chair, and I’ll be the young prince and hit thee a box on the ear, and then thou shalt say, to teach you what prerogatives mean, I commit you to the Fleet.

sp.speaker: John
sp.p: Come on, I’ll be your judge. But thou shalt not hit me hard?

sp.speaker: Derrick
sp.p: No, no.

stage.supplied: John sits in the lord chief justice’s chair.

sp.speaker: John
sp.p: What hath he done?

sp.speaker: Derrick
sp.p: Marry, he hath robbed Derrick.

sp.speaker: John
sp.p: Why, then, I cannot let him go.

sp.speaker: Derrick
sp.p: I must needs have my man.

sp.speaker: John
sp.p: You shall not have him.

sp.speaker: Derrick
sp.p: Shall I not have my man? Say No an you dare! How say you, shall I not have my man?

sp.speaker: John
sp.p: No, marry, shall you not.

sp.speaker: Derrick
sp.p: Shall I not, John?

sp.speaker: John
sp.p: No, Derrick.

sp.speaker: Derrick
sp.p: Why, then, take you that ’til more come. Derrick gives John a box on the ear Zounds, shall I not have him?

sp.speaker: John
sp.p: Well, I am content to take this at your hand, but, I pray you, who am I?

sp.speaker: Derrick
sp.p: Who art thou? Zounds, dost not know thyself?

sp.speaker: John
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Derrick
sp.p: Now away, simple fellow! Why man, thou art John the Cobbler.

sp.speaker: John
sp.p: No, I am my Lord Chief Justice of England.

sp.speaker: Derrick
sp.p: Oh, John, mass, thou say’st true, thou art indeed.

sp.speaker: John
sp.p: Why, then, to teach you what prerogatives mean I commit you to the Fleet.

sp.speaker: Derrick
sp.p:
Well, I will go, but, i’faith, you grey-beard knave, I’ll course you.
Exit and straight enters again.
O John, come, come out of thy chair! Why, what a clown wert thou to let me hit thee a box on the ear, and now thou seest they will not take me to the Fleet! I think that thou art one of these workaday clowns.

sp.speaker: John
sp.p: But I marvel what will become of thee.

sp.speaker: Derrick
sp.p: Faith, I’ll be no more a carrier.

sp.speaker: John
sp.p: What wilt thou do, then?

sp.speaker: Derrick
sp.p: I’ll dwell with thee and be a cobbler.

sp.speaker: John
sp.p: With me? Alas, I am not able to keep thee. Why, thou wilt eat me out of doors.

sp.speaker: Derrick
sp.p: O John, no John, I am none of these great slouching fellows that devour these great pieces of beef and brewis. Alas, a trifle serves me. A woodcock, a chicken, or a capon’s leg, or any such little thing serves me.

sp.speaker: John
sp.p: A capon! Why, man, I cannot get a capon once a year, except it be at Christmas at some other man’s house, for we cobblers be glad of a dish of roots.

sp.speaker: Derrick
sp.p: Roots? Why, are you so good at rooting? Nay, cobbler, we’ll have you ringed.

lg.l: Yet will we have in store

sp.speaker: Derrick
sp.p: A bots on you! An’t be but for your ale, I’ll dwell with you. Come, let’s away as fast as we can.

div.stage: Enter the young Prince Henry with Ned and Tom.

sp.speaker: Prince Henry
sp.p: Come away, sirs. Gog’s wounds, Ned, didst thou not see what a box on the ear I took my Lord Chief Justice?

sp.speaker: Tom
sp.p: By Gog’s blood, it did me good to see it. It made his teeth jar in his head.

sp.speaker: Prince Henry
sp.p: How now, Sir John Oldcastle. What news with you?

sp.speaker: Jockey
sp.p: I am glad to see your grace at liberty. I was come, I, to visit you in prison.

sp.speaker: Prince Henry
sp.p: To visit me! Didst thou not know that I am a prince’s son? Why, ’tis enough for me to look into a prison, though I come not in myself. But here’s such ado nowadays, here’s prisoning, here’s hanging, whipping, and the devil and all! But I tell you, sirs, when I am king we will have no such things. But, my lads, if the old king my father were dead, we would be all kings.

sp.speaker: Jockey
sp.p: He is a good old man. God take him to His mercy the sooner.

sp.speaker: Prince Henry
sp.p: But, Ned, so soon as I am king, the first thing I will do shall be to put my Lord Chief Justice out of office, and thou shalt be my lord chief justice of England.

sp.speaker: Ned
sp.p: Shall I be lord chief justice? By Gog’s wounds, I’ll be the bravest lord chief justice that ever was in England!

sp.speaker: Prince Henry
sp.p: Then, Ned, I’ll turn all these prisons into fence schools, and I will endow thee with them, with lands to maintain them withal. Then I will have a bout with my Lord Chief Justice! Thou shalt hang none but pick-purses and horse-stealers, and such base-minded villains. But that fellow that will stand by the highway side courageously with his sword and buckler and take a purse, that fellow give him commendations; besides that, send him to me and I will give him an annual pension out of my exchequer to maintain him all the days of his life.

sp.speaker: Jockey
sp.p: Nobly spoken, Harry! We shall never have a merry world ’til the old king be dead.

sp.speaker: Ned
sp.p: But whither are ye going now?

sp.speaker: Prince Henry
sp.p: To the court, for I hear say my father lies very sick.

sp.speaker: Tom
sp.p: But I doubt he will not die.

sp.speaker: Prince Henry
sp.p: Yet will I go thither, for the breath shall be no sooner out of his mouth but I will clap the crown on my head.

sp.speaker: Jockey
sp.p: Will you go to the court with that cloak, so full of needles?

sp.speaker: Prince Henry
sp.p: Cloak, eyelet-holes, needles, and all was of mine own devising, and therefore I will wear it.

sp.speaker: Tom
sp.p: I pray you, my lord, what may be the meaning thereof?

sp.speaker: Prince Henry
sp.p: Why, man, ’tis a sign that I stand upon thorns ’til the crown be on my head.

sp.speaker: Jockey
sp.p: Or that every needle might be a prick to their hearts that repine at your doings.

sp.speaker: Prince Henry
sp.p: Thou say’st true, Jockey. But there’s some will say, the young prince will be a well-toward young man, and all this gear, that I had as lief they would break my head with a pot as to say any such thing. But we stand prating here too long. I must needs speak with my father; therefore come away.

sp.speaker: Porter
sp.p: What a rapping keep you at the king’s court gate?

sp.speaker: Prince Henry
sp.p: Here’s one that must speak with the king.

sp.speaker: Porter
sp.p: The king is very sick, and none must speak with him.

sp.speaker: Prince Henry
sp.p: No, you rascal? Do you not know me?

sp.speaker: Porter
sp.p: You are my lord the young prince.

sp.speaker: Prince Henry
sp.p: Then go and tell my father that I must and will speak with him.

sp.speaker: Ned
sp.p: Shall I cut off his head?

sp.speaker: Prince Henry
sp.p: No, no. Though I would help you in other places, yet I have nothing to do here. What, you are in my father’s court!

sp.speaker: Ned
sp.p: I will write him in my tables, for so soon as I am made lord chief justice, I will put him out of his office.

sp.speaker: Prince Henry
sp.p: Gog’s wounds, sirs, the king comes. Let’s all stand aside.

div.stage: Enter the King Henry IV with the Lord of Exeter.

sp.speaker: Henry IV
sp.p: And is it true, my lord, that my son is already sent to the Fleet? Now truly that man is more fitter to rule the realm than I, for by no means could I rule my son, and he by one word hath caused him to be ruled. O my son, my son, no sooner out of one prison but into another! I had thought, once, while I had lived to have seen this noble realm of England flourish by thee, my son, but now I see it goes to ruin and decay.

div.stage: He weepeth. Enter the Lord of Oxford.

sp.speaker: Oxford
sp.p: An please your grace, here is my lord your son, that cometh to speak with you. He sayeth he must and will speak with you.

sp.speaker: Henry IV
sp.p: Who, my son Harry?

sp.speaker: Oxford
sp.p: Ay, an please your majesty.

sp.speaker: Henry IV
sp.p: I know wherefore he cometh, but look that none come with him.

sp.speaker: Oxford
sp.p: A very disordered company, and such as make very ill rule in your majesty’s house.

sp.speaker: Henry IV
sp.p: Well, let him come, but look that none come with him.

div.stage: Oxfordgoeth across the stage to address Prince Henry.

sp.speaker: Oxford
sp.p: An please your grace, my lord the king sends for you.

sp.speaker: Prince Henry
sp.p: Come away, sirs. Let’s go all together.

sp.speaker: Oxford
sp.p: An please your grace, none must go with you.

sp.speaker: Prince Henry
sp.p: Why, I must needs have them with me. Otherwise I can do my father no countenance. Therefore, come away.

sp.speaker: Oxford
sp.p: The king your father commands there should none come.

sp.speaker: Prince Henry
sp.p: Well, sirs, then be gone, and provide me three noise of musicians.

div.stage: Exeunt Knights Ned, Tom, and Jockey.
The Prince crosses the stage to Henry IV with a dagger in his hand.

sp.speaker: Henry IV
sp.p: Come, my son, come on in God’s name! I know wherefore thy coming is. O my son, my son, what cause hath ever been, that thou shouldst forsake me and follow this vile and reprobate company which abuseth youth so manifestly? O my son, thou knowest that these thy doings will end thy father’s days. He weeps. Ay, so, so, my son, thou fearest not to approach the presence of thy sick father in that disguised sort. I tell thee, my son, that there is never a needle in thy cloak but it is a prick to my heart, and never an eyelet-hole but it is a hole to my soul, and wherefore thou bringest that dagger in thy hand I know not but by conjecture.

sp.speaker: Prince Henry
sp.p: Aside My conscience accuseth me. To Henry IV Most sovereign lord and well-beloved father, to answer first to the last point. That is, whereas you conjecture that this hand and this dagger shall be armed against your life, no, know, my beloved father, far be the thoughts of your son — son, said I? An unworthy son for so good a father — but far be the thoughts of any such pretended mischief, and I most humbly render it to your majesty’s hand.Prince Henry gives Henry IV the dagger. And live, my lord and sovereign, forever and with your dagger arm show like vengeance upon the body of that your son, I was about to say and dare not, ah woe is me! — therefore, that your wild slave. ’Tis not the crown that I come for, sweet father, because I am unworthy, and those vile and reprobate companions I abandon and utterly abolish their company forever. Pardon, sweet father, pardon: the least thing and most desired. And this ruffianly cloak I here tear from my back and sacrifice it to the devil, which is master of all mischief. Pardon me, sweet father, pardon me. Good my lord of Exeter, speak for me. Pardon me, pardon, good father. Not a word? Ah, he will not speak one word. Ah, Harry, now thrice unhappy Harry! But what shall I do? I will go take me into some solitary place and there lament my sinful life, and when I have done I will lay me down and die.

sp.speaker: Henry IV
sp.p: Call him again. Call my son again.

sp.speaker: Prince Henry
sp.p: And doth my father call me again? Now, Harry, happy be the time that thy father calleth thee again.

sp.speaker: Henry IV
sp.p: Stand up, my son, and do not think thy father but at the request of thee, my son, I will pardon thee. And God bless thee and make thee his servant.

sp.speaker: Prince Henry
sp.p: Thanks, good my lord, and no doubt but this day, even this day, I am born new again.

sp.speaker: Henry IV
sp.p: Come, my son and lords, take me by the hands.

sp.speaker: Derrick
sp.p: Shouts to offstage Thou art a stinking whore, and a whoreson stinking whore! Dost think I’ll take it at thy hands?

sp.speaker: John
sp.p: Derrick, Derrick, Derrick! Hearest a? Do, Derrick, never while thou livest use that! Why, what will my neighbors say an thou go away so?

sp.speaker: Derrick
sp.p: She’s a narrant whore, and I’ll have the law on you, John.

sp.speaker: John
sp.p: Why, what hath she done?

sp.speaker: Derrick
sp.p: Marry, mark thou, John. I will prove it, that I will!

sp.speaker: John
sp.p: What wilt thou prove?

sp.speaker: Derrick
sp.p: That she called me in to dinner — John, mark the tale well, John — and, when I was set, she brought me a dish of roots and a piece of barrel butter therein. And she is a very knave, and thou a drab if thou take her part.

sp.speaker: John
sp.p: Hearest a, Derrick, is this the matter? Nay, an it be no worse, we will go home again, and all shall be amended.

sp.speaker: Derrick
sp.p: O John, hearest a, John, is all well?

sp.speaker: John
sp.p: Ay, all is well.

sp.speaker: Derrick
sp.p: Then I’ll go home before and break all the glass windows.

div.head: Scene 8; Video Sc. 8
div.stage: Enter the King with his Lords Exeter and Oxford.

sp.speaker: Henry IV
sp.p: Come, my lords, I see it boots me not to take any physic, for all the physicians in the world cannot cure me, no not one. But good my lords, remember my last will and testament concerning my son, for truly, my lords, I do not think but he will prove as valiant and victorious a king as ever reigned in England.

sp.speaker: Exeter, and Oxford
sp.p: Let heaven and earth be witness between us, if we accomplish not thy will to the uttermost.

sp.speaker: Henry IV
sp.p: I give you most unfeigned thanks, good my lords. Draw the curtains and depart my chamber awhile and cause some music to rock me asleep.

div.stage: Music plays, and he sleepeth. Enter the Prince.

sp.speaker: Prince Henry
sp.p: Ah Harry, thrice-unhappy, that hath neglect so long from visiting of thy sick father. I will go. Nay, but why do I not go to the chamber of my sick father to comfort the melancholy soul of his body? His soul, said I? Here is his body indeed, but his soul is whereas it needs no body. Now thrice-accursed Harry, that hath offended thy father so much, and could not I crave pardon for all! O my dying father, cursed be the day wherein I was born, and accursed be the hour wherein I was begotten! But what shall I do? If weeping tears which come too late may suffice the negligence neglected to some, I will weep day and night until the fountain be dry with weeping.

div.stage: Exit Prince Henry, with Henry IV’s crown.
Enter Lords of Exeter and Oxford.

sp.speaker: Exeter
sp.p: Come easily, my lord, for waking of the king.

sp.speaker: Henry IV
sp.p: Now, my lords.

sp.speaker: Oxford
sp.p: How doth your grace feel yourself?

sp.speaker: Henry IV
sp.p: Somewhat better after my sleep. But, good my lords, take off my crown, remove my chair a little back, and set me right.

sp.speaker: Exeter, and Oxford
sp.p: An please your grace, the crown is taken away.

sp.speaker: Henry IV
sp.p: The crown taken away! Good my lord of Oxford, go see who hath done this deed. Exit Oxford No doubt ’tis some vile traitor that hath done it to deprive my son. They that would do it now would seek to scrape and scrawl for it after my death.

div.stage: Enter Lord of Oxford with the Prince holding the crown.

sp.speaker: Oxford
sp.p: Here, an please your grace, is my lord the young prince with the crown.

sp.speaker: Henry IV
sp.p: Why, how now, my son? I had thought the last time I had you in schooling I had given you a lesson for all, and do you now begin again? Why tell me, my son, dost thou think the time so long that thou wouldst have it before the breath be out of my mouth?

sp.speaker: Prince Henry
sp.p: Most sovereign lord and well-beloved father, I came into your chamber to comfort the melancholy soul of your body, and finding you at that time past all recovery and dead, to my thinking, God is my witness, and what should I do but with weeping tears lament the death of you, my father? And after that, seeing the crown, I took it. And tell me, my father, who might better take it than I after your death? But, seeing you live, I most humbly render it into your majesty’s hands, and the happiest man alive that my father live. And live, my lord and father, forever.

stage.supplied: Prince Henry gives Henry IV the crown and kneels before him.

sp.speaker: Henry IV
sp.p: Stand up, my son. Thine answer hath sounded well in mine ears, for I must needs confess that I was in a very sound sleep and altogether unmindful of thy coming. But come near, my son, and let me put thee in possession whilst I live, that none deprive thee of it after my death.

sp.speaker: Prince Henry
sp.p: Well may I take it at your majesty’s hands, but it shall never touch my head so long as my father lives.

div.stage: He Prince Henry taketh the crown.

sp.speaker: Henry IV
sp.p: God give thee joy, my son. God bless thee and make thee His servant and send thee a prosperous reign, for God knows, my son, how hardly I came by it and how hardly I have maintained it.

sp.speaker: Prince Henry
sp.p: Howsoever you came by it, I know not, but now I have it from you, and from you I will keep it. And he that seeks to take the crown from my head, let him look that his armor be thicker than mine, or I will pierce him to the heart, were it harder than brass or bullion.

sp.speaker: Henry IV
sp.p: Nobly spoken, and like a king. Now trust me, my lords, I fear not but my son will be as warlike and victorious a prince as ever reigned in England.

sp.speaker: Exeter, and Oxford
sp.p: His former life shows no less.

sp.speaker: Henry IV
sp.p: Well, my lords, I know not whether it be for sleep or drawing near of drowsy summer of death, but I am very much given to sleep. Therefore, good my lords and my son, draw the curtains, depart my chamber, and cause some music to rock me asleep.

stage.supplied: Exeter, Oxford, and Prince Henry draw the curtains.

div.stage: Exeunt omnes Exeter, Oxford, and Prince Henry.

sp.speaker: Cutbert Cutter
sp.p: Ah God, I am now much like to a bird which hath escaped out of the cage, for so soon as my Lord Chief Justice heard that the old king was dead, he was glad to let me go, for fear of my lord the young prince. But here comes some of his companions. I will see an I can get anything of them, for old acquaintance.

div.stage: Enter Knights Tom, Jockey, and Ned ranging.

sp.speaker: Tom
sp.p: Gog’s wounds, the king is dead!

sp.speaker: Jockey
sp.p: Dead! Then Gog’s blood, we shall be all kings!

sp.speaker: Ned
sp.p: Gog’s wounds, I shall be lord chief justice of England.

sp.speaker: Tom
sp.p: To Cutbert Cutter Why, how are you broken out of prison?

sp.speaker: Ned
sp.p: Gog’s wounds, how the villain stinks!

sp.speaker: Jockey
sp.p: Why, what will become of thee now? Fie upon him, how the rascal stinks.

sp.speaker: Cutbert Cutter
sp.p: Marry, I will go and serve my master again.

sp.speaker: Tom
sp.p: Gog’s blood, dost think that he will have any such scabbed knave as thou art? What, man, he is a king now.

sp.speaker: Ned
sp.p: Hold thee, here’s a couple of angels for thee, and get thee gone, for the king will not be long before he come this way. And hereafter I will tell the king of thee.

sp.speaker: Jockey
sp.p: Oh, how it did me good to see the king when he was crowned! Methought his seat was like the figure of heaven and his person like unto a god.

sp.speaker: Ned
sp.p: But who would have thought that the king would have changed his countenance so?

sp.speaker: Jockey
sp.p: Did you not see with what grace he sent his embassage into France to tell the French king that Harry of England hath sent for the crown and Harry of England will have it?

sp.speaker: Tom
sp.p: But ’twas but a little to make the people believe that he was sorry for his father’s death.

sp.speaker: Ned
sp.p: Gog’s wounds, the king comes. Let’s all stand aside.

div.stage: Enter the King Henry V with the Archbishop of Canterbury, and the Lord of Oxford.

sp.speaker: Jockey
sp.p: How do you, my lord?

sp.speaker: Ned
sp.p: How now, Harry? Tut, my lord, put away these dumps. You are a king, and all the realm is yours. What, man, do you not remember the old sayings? You know I must be lord chief justice of England. Trust me, my lord, methinks you are very much changed, and ’tis but with a little sorrowing to make folks believe the death of your father grieves you, and ’tis nothing so.

sp.speaker: Henry V
sp.p: I prithee, Ned, mend thy manners and be more modester in thy terms, for my unfeigned grief is not to be ruled by thy flattering and dissembling talk. Thou say’st I am changed. So I am indeed, and so must thou be, and that quickly, or else I must cause thee to be changed.

sp.speaker: Jockey
sp.p: Gog’s wounds! How like you this? Zounds, ’tis not so sweet as music.

sp.speaker: Tom
sp.p: I trust we have not offended your grace no way.

sp.speaker: Henry V
sp.p:
Ah, Tom, your former life grieves me and makes me to abandon and abolish your company forever, and therefore not upon pain of death to approach my presence by ten miles’ space. Then, if I hear well of you, it may be I will do somewhat for you; otherwise, look for no more favor at my hands than at any other man’s. And therefore be gone. We have other matters to talk on.
Exeunt Knights Tom, Ned, and Jockey.
Now, my good lord archbishop of Canterbury, what say you to our embassage into France?

sp.speaker: Canterbury
sp.p: Your right to the French crown of France came by your great-grandmother Isabel, wife to King Edward the Third and sister to Charles the French king. Now, if the French king deny it, as likely enough he will, then must you take your sword in hand and conquer the right. Let the usurped Frenchman know , although your predecessors have let it pass, you will not, for your countrymen are willing with purse and men to aid you. Then, my good lord, as it hath been always known that Scotland hath been in league with France by a sort of pensions which yearly come from thence, I think it therefore best to conquer Scotland, and then I think that you may go more easily into France. And this is all that I can say, my good lord.

sp.speaker: Henry V
sp.p: I thank you, my good lord archbishop of Canterbury. What say you, my good lord of Oxford?

sp.speaker: Oxford
sp.p: An please your majesty, I agree to my lord archbishop, saving in this: he that will Scotland win must first with France begin, according to the old saying. Therefore, my good lord, I think it best first to invade France, for in conquering Scotland you conquer but one; an conquer France and conquer both.

sp.speaker: Exeter
sp.p: An please your majesty, my lord ambassador is come out of France.

sp.speaker: Henry V
sp.p: Now trust me, my lord, he was the last man that we talked of. I am glad that he is come to resolve us of our answer. Commit him to our presence.

sp.speaker: York
sp.p: God save the life of my sovereign lord the king.

sp.speaker: Henry V
sp.p: Now, my good lord the duke of York, what news from our brother the French king?

sp.speaker: York
sp.p: An please your majesty, I delivered him my embassage, whereof I took some deliberation. But for the answer, he hath sent my lord ambassador of Bruges, the duke of Burgundy, Monsieur le Cole, with two hundred and fifty horsemen, to bring the embassage.

sp.speaker: Henry V
sp.p:
Commit my lord archbishop of Bruges into our presence.
Enter Archbishop of Bruges.
Now, my lord archbishop of Bruges, we do learn by our lord ambassador that you have our message to do from our brother the French king. Here, my good lord, according to our accustomed order, we give you free liberty and licence to speak with good audience.

sp.speaker: Bruges
sp.p: God save the mighty king of England. My lord and master, the most Christian king, Charles the Sixth, the great and mighty king of France, as a most noble and Christian king, not minding to shed innocent blood, is rather content to yield somewhat to your unreasonable demands, that if fifty thousand crowns a year with his daughter, the said Lady Katherine, in marriage, and some crowns which he may well spare, not hurting of his kingdom, he is content to yield so far to your unreasonable desire.

sp.speaker: Henry V
sp.p: Why, then, belike your lord and master thinks to puff me up with fifty thousand crowns a year. No, tell thy lord and master that all the crowns in France shall not serve me, except the crown and kingdom itself — and perchance hereafter I will have his daughter.

sp.speaker: Bruges
sp.p: An it please your majesty, my lord Prince Dauphin greets you well with this present.

div.stage: He delivereth a tun of tennis balls.

sp.speaker: Henry V
sp.p: What, a gilded tun? I pray you, my lord of York, look what is in it.

sp.speaker: York
sp.p: An please your grace, here is a carpet and a tun of tennis balls.

sp.speaker: Henry V
sp.p: A tun of tennis balls? I pray you, good my lord archbishop, what might the meaning thereof be?

sp.speaker: Bruges
sp.p: An it please you, my lord, a messenger, you know, ought to keep close his message, and specially an ambassador.

sp.speaker: Henry V
sp.p: But I know that you may declare your message to a king. The law of arms allows no less.

sp.speaker: Bruges
sp.p: My lord, hearing of your wildness before your father’s death, sent you this, my good lord, meaning that you are more fitter for a tennis court than a field and more fitter for a carpet than the camp.

sp.speaker: Henry V
sp.p: My lord Prince Dauphin is very pleasant with me. But tell him that instead of balls of leather we will toss him balls of brass and iron, yea, such balls as never were tossed in France. The proudest tennis court shall rue it; ay, and thou, prince of Bruges, shall rue it. Therefore get thee hence and tell him thy message quickly, lest I be there before thee. Away, priest, be gone.

sp.speaker: Bruges
sp.p: I beseech your grace to deliver me your safe conduct under your broad seal manual.

sp.speaker: Henry V
sp.p:
Priest of Bruges, know that the hand and seal of a king, and his word is all one, and instead of my hand and seal I will bring him my hand and sword. And tell thy lord and master that I, Harry of England, said it and I, Harry of England, will perform it. My lord of York, deliver him our safe conduct under our broad seal manual.
Exeunt Archbishop of Bruges, and the Duke of York.
Now, my lords, to arms, to arms, for I vow by heaven and earth that the proudest Frenchman in all France shall rue the time that ever these tennis balls were sent into England. To Exeter My lord, I will that there be provided a great navy of ships with all speed at Southampton, for there I mean to ship my men, for I would be there before him, if it were possible. Therefore come — but stay, I had almost forgot the chiefest thing of all, with chafing with this French ambassador. Call in my Lord Chief Justice of England.

div.stage: Enter Lord Chief Justice of England.

sp.speaker: Exeter
sp.p: Here is the king, my lord.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Justice
sp.p: God preserve your majesty.

sp.speaker: Henry V
sp.p: Why, how now, my lord, what is the matter?

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Justice
sp.p: I would it were unknown to your majesty.

sp.speaker: Henry V
sp.p: Why, what ails you?

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Justice
sp.p: Your majesty knoweth my grief well.

sp.speaker: Henry V
sp.p: Oh, my lord, you remember you sent me to the Fleet, did you not?

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Justice
sp.p: I trust your grace have forgotten that.

sp.speaker: Henry V
sp.p: Ay, truly my lord, and for revengement I have chosen you to be my protector over my realm until it shall please God to give me speedy return out of France.

sp.speaker: Lord Chief Justice
sp.p: An if it please your majesty, I am far unworthy of so high a dignity.

sp.speaker: Henry V
sp.p: Tut, my lord, you are not unworthy, because I think you worthy. For you that would not spare me, I think, will not spare another. It must needs be so, and, therefore, come, let us be gone and get our men in a readiness.

div.head: Scene 10; Video Sc. 10
div.stage: Enter a Captain, John Cobbler, and his Wife.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Come, come, there’s no remedy. Thou must needs serve the king.

sp.speaker: John
sp.p: Good Master Captain, let me go. I am not able to go so far.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: I pray you, good Master Captain, be good to my husband.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Why, I am sure he is not too good to serve the king?

sp.speaker: John
sp.p: Alas, no, but a great deal too bad. Therefore I pray you let me go.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: No, no, thou shalt go.

sp.speaker: John
sp.p: Oh, sir, I have a great many shoes at home to cobble.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: I pray you let him go home again.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Tush, I care not. Thou shalt go.

sp.speaker: John
sp.p: Oh, wife, an you had been a loving wife to me, this had not been, for I have said many times that I would go away, and now I must go against my will.

div.stage: He weepeth. Enter Derrick with a pot lid for a shield.

sp.speaker: Derrick
sp.p: How now! Ho, basillus manus, for an old codpiece! Master Captain, shall we away? Zounds, how now, John, what, a-crying? What make you and my dame there? To Wife I marvel whose head you will throw the stools at now we are gone.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: I’ll tell you! Come, ye cloghead, what do you with my pot lid? Hear you, will you have it rapped about your pate?

div.stage: She beateth him with her pot lid.

sp.speaker: Derrick
sp.p: Oh, good dame!Here he shakes her. An I had my dagger here, I would worry you all to pieces, that I would.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: Would you so? I’ll try that.

sp.speaker: Derrick
sp.p:
Master Captain, will ye suffer her? Go to, dame! I will go back as far as I can, but, an you come again, I’ll clap the law on your back, that’s flat. I’ll tell you, Master Captain, what you shall do. Press her for a soldier. I warrant you, she will do as much good as her husband and I too.
Enter the Thief Cutbert Cutter.
Zounds, who comes yonder?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: How now, good fellow. Dost thou want a master?

sp.speaker: Cutbert Cutter
sp.p: Ay, truly sir.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Hold thee, then. I press thee for a soldier to serve the king in France.

sp.speaker: Derrick
sp.p: How now, Gads! What, dost know’s, thinkest?

sp.speaker: Cutbert Cutter
sp.p: Ay, I knew thee long ago.

sp.speaker: Derrick
sp.p: Hear you, Master Captain?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: What say’st thou?

sp.speaker: Derrick
sp.p: I pray you let me go home again.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Why, what wouldst thou do at home?

sp.speaker: Derrick
sp.p: Marry, I have brought two shirts with me, and I would carry one of them home again, for I am sure he’ll steal it from me, he is such a filching fellow.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: I warrant thee he will not steal it from thee. Come, let’s away.

sp.speaker: Derrick
sp.p: Come, Master Captain, let’s away. Come, follow me.

sp.speaker: John
sp.p: Come, wife, let’s part lovingly.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: Farewell, good husband.

sp.speaker: Derrick
sp.p: Fie, what a kissing and crying is here! To Wife Zounds, do ye think he will never come again? To John Why, John, come away! Dost think that we are so base-minded to die among Frenchmen? Zounds, we know not whether they will lay us in their church or no. Come, Master Captain, let’s away.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: I cannot stay no longer, therefore come away.

div.stage: Enter the King Charles VI of France, Prince Dauphin, and Lord High Constable of France.

sp.speaker: Charles VI
sp.p: Now, my lord high constable, what say you to our embassage into England?

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.p: An it please your majesty, I can say nothing until my lords ambassadors be come home, but yet methinks your grace hath done well to get your men in so good a readiness for fear of the worst.

sp.speaker: Charles VI
sp.p: Ay, my lord, we have some in a readiness, but if the king of England make against us we must have thrice so many more.

sp.speaker: Dauphin
sp.p: Tut, my lord, although the king of England be young and wild-headed, yet never think he will be so unwise to make battle against the mighty king of France.

sp.speaker: Charles VI
sp.p: Oh, my son, although the king of England be young and wild-headed, yet never think but he is ruled by his wise counselors.

sp.speaker: Bruges
sp.p: God save the life of my sovereign lord the king.

sp.speaker: Charles VI
sp.p: Now, my good lord archbishop of Bruges, what news from our brother the English king?

sp.speaker: Bruges
sp.p: An please your majesty, he is so far from your expectation that nothing will serve him but the crown and kingdom itself. Besides, he bade me haste quickly, lest he be there before me, and, so far as I hear, he hath kept promise, for they say he is already landed at Kidcocks in Normandy, upon the river of Seine, and laid his siege to the garrison town of Harfleur.

sp.speaker: Charles VI
sp.p: You have made great haste in the meantime, have you not?

sp.speaker: Dauphin
sp.p: I pray you, my lord, how did the king of England take my presents?

sp.speaker: Bruges
sp.p: Truly, my lord, in very ill part. For these your balls of leather, he will toss you balls of brass and iron. Trust me, my lord, I was very afraid of him. He is such a haughty and high-minded prince, he is as fierce as a lion.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.p: Tush, we will make him as tame as a lamb, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.p: God save the mighty king of France.

sp.speaker: Charles VI
sp.p: Now, messenger, what news?

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.p: An it please your majesty, I come from your poor distressed town of Harfleur, which is so beset on every side, if your majesty do not send present aid the town will be yielded to the English king.

sp.speaker: Charles VI
sp.p: Come, my lords, come, shall we stand still ’til our country be spoiled under our noses? My lords, let the Normans, Brabants, Pickardies, and Danes be sent for with all speed. And you, my lord high constable, I make general over all my whole army, Monsieur le Cole, Master of the Bows, Signor Devens, and all the rest, at your appointment.

sp.speaker: Dauphin
sp.p: I trust your majesty will bestow some part of the battle on me. I hope not to present any otherwise than well.

sp.speaker: Charles VI
sp.p: I tell thee, my son, although I should get the victory, an thou lose thy life, I should think myself quite conquered and the Englishmen to have the victory.

sp.speaker: Dauphin
sp.p: Why, my lord and father, I would have the petty king of England to know that I dare encounter him in any ground of the world.

sp.speaker: Charles VI
sp.p: I know well, my son, but at this time I will have it thus. Therefore come away.

div.stage: Enter Henry the Fifth, with his Lords.

sp.speaker: Henry V
sp.p: Come, my lords of England, no doubt this good luck of winning this town is a sign of an honorable victory to come. But, good my lord, go and speak to the captains with all speed to number the host of the Frenchmen, and by that means we may the better know how to appoint the battle.

sp.speaker: York
sp.p: An it please your majesty, there are many of your men sick and diseased, and many of them die for want of victuals.

sp.speaker: Henry V
sp.p: And why did you not tell me of it before? If we cannot have it for money, we will have it by dint of sword. The laws of arms allow no less.

sp.speaker: Oxford
sp.p: I beseech your grace to grant me a boon.

sp.speaker: Henry V
sp.p: What is that, my good lord?

sp.speaker: Oxford
sp.p: That your grace would give me the vanguard in the battle.

sp.speaker: Henry V
sp.p:
Trust me, my lord of Oxford, I cannot, for I have already given it to my uncle the duke of York. Yet I thank you for your good will.
A trumpet sounds.
How now, what is that?

sp.speaker: York
sp.p: I think it be some herald of arms.

sp.speaker: Herald
sp.p: King of England, my lord high constable and others of the noblemen of France sends me to defy thee as open enemy to God, our country, and us, and hereupon they presently bid thee battle.

sp.speaker: Henry V
sp.p: Herald, tell them that I defy them as open enemies to God, my country, and me, and as wrongful usurpers of my right. And whereas thou say’st they presently bid me battle, tell them that I think they know how to please me. But, I pray thee, what place hath my lord Prince Dauphin here in battle?

sp.speaker: Herald
sp.p: An it please your grace, my lord and king his father will not let him come into the field.

sp.speaker: Henry V
sp.p:
Why, then, he doth me great injury. I thought that he and I should have played at tennis together. Therefore I have brought tennis balls for him, but other manner of ones than he sent me. And, herald, tell my lord Prince Dauphin that I have inured my hands with other kind of weapons than tennis balls ere this time o’ day and that he shall find it ere it be long. And so adieu, my friend, and tell my lord that I am ready when he will.
Exit Herald.
Come, my lords, I care not an I go to our captains, and I’ll see the number of the French army myself. Strike up the drum.

sp.speaker: 1 French Soldier
sp.p: Come away, Jack Drummer, come away all, and me will tell you what me will do. Me will tro one chance on the dice, who shall have the king of England and his lords.

sp.speaker: 2 French Soldier
sp.p: Come away, Jack Drummer, and tro your chance, and lay down your drum.

sp.speaker: Drummer
sp.p: Oh, the brave apparel that the Englishmans hay broth over! I will tell you what me ha’ done, me ha’ provided a hundreth trunks, and all to put the fine ’parel of the Englishmans in.

sp.speaker: 1 French Soldier
sp.p: What do thou mean by trunk, eh?

sp.speaker: 2 French Soldier
sp.p: A shest, man, a hundred shests.

sp.speaker: 1 French Soldier
sp.p: Awee, awee, awee. Me will tell you what, me ha’ put five shildren out of my house, and all too little to put the fine apparel of the Englishmans in.

sp.speaker: Drummer
sp.p:
Oh, the brave, the brave apparel that we shall have anon. But come, and you shall see what me will tro at the king’s Drummer and Fife.
He throws dice.
Ha, me ha’ no good luck! Tro you.

sp.speaker: 3 French Soldier
sp.p: Faith, me will tro at the earl of Northumberland and my lord of Willoughby, with his great horse, snorting, farting - oh, brave horse!

sp.speaker: 1 French Soldier
sp.p:
Ha, by’r Lady you ha’ reasonable good luck. Now I will tro at the king himself.
He throws dice.
Ha, me have no good luck.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: How now, what make you here, so far from the camp?

sp.speaker: 2 French Soldier
sp.p: Shall me tell our captain what we have done here?

sp.speaker: Drummer
sp.p: Awee, awee.

sp.speaker: 2 French Soldier
sp.p: I will tell you what we have done. We have been troing our shance on the dice, but none can win the king.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: I think so. Why, he is left behind for me, and I have set three or four chair-makers a-work to make a new disguised chair to set that womanly king of England in, that all the people may laugh and scoff at him.

sp.speaker: 2 French Soldier
sp.p: O brave captain!

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: I am glad, and yet with a kind of pity, to see the poor king. Why, whoever saw a more flourishing army in France in one day than here is? Are not here all the peers of France? Are not here the Normans with their fiery handguns and slaunching curtle-axes? Are not here the Barbarians with their bard horses and launching spears? Are not here Pickards with their cross-bows and piercing darts? The Hainuyers with their cutting glaives and sharp carbuncles? Are not here the lance-knights of Burgundy? And on the other side, a sight of poor English scabs? Why, take an Englishman out of his warm bed and his stale drink but one month and, alas, what will become of him? But give the Frenchman a radish root and he will live with it all the days of his life.

sp.speaker: 2 French Soldier
sp.p: Oh, the brave apparel that we shall have of the Englishmans!

div.stage: Enter the King of England and his Lords.

sp.speaker: Henry V
sp.p: Come, my lords and fellows of arms, what company is there of the Frenchmen?

sp.speaker: Oxford
sp.p: An it please your majesty, our captains have numbered them, and, so near as they can judge, they are about threescore thousand horsemen and forty thousand footmen.

sp.speaker: Henry V
sp.p: They threescore thousand, and we but two thousand. They forty thousand footmen, and we twelve thousand. They are a hundred thousand, and we fourteen thousand: ten to one. My lords and loving countrymen, though we be few and they many, fear not. Your quarrel is good, and God will defend you. Pluck up your hearts, for this day we shall either have a valiant victory or an honorable death. Now, my lords, I will that my uncle the duke of York have the vanguard in the battle. The earl of Derby, the earl of Oxford, the earl of Kent, the earl of Nottingham, the earl of Huntington, I will have beside the army, that they may come fresh upon them. And I myself with the duke of Bedford, the duke of Clarence, and the duke of Gloucester will be in the midst of the battle. Furthermore, I will that my lord of Willoughby and the earl of Northumberland with their troops of horsemen be continually running like wings on both sides of the army, my lord of Northumberland on the left wing. Then I will that every archer provide him a stake of a tree and sharp it at both ends and, at the first encounter of the horsemen, to pitch their stakes down into the ground before them, that they may gore themselves upon them, and then to recoil back and shoot wholly altogether and so discomfit them.

sp.speaker: Oxford
sp.p: An it please your majesty, I will take that in charge, if your grace be therewith content.

sp.speaker: Henry V
sp.p: With all my heart, my good lord of Oxford, and go and provide quickly.

sp.speaker: Oxford
sp.p: I thank your highness.

sp.speaker: Henry V
sp.p:
Well, my lords, our battles are ordained, and the French making of bonfires and at their banquets. But let them look, for I mean to set upon them.
The trumpet sounds.
Soft, here comes some other French message.

sp.speaker: Herald
sp.p: King of England, my lord high constable and other of my lords, considering the poor estate of thee and thy poor countrymen, send me to know what thou wilt give for thy ransom. Perhaps thou mayst agree better cheap now than when thou art conquered.

sp.speaker: Henry V
sp.p: Why, then belike your high constable sends to know what I will give for my ransom? Now, trust me, herald, not so much as a tun of tennis balls. No, not so much as one poor tennis ball. Rather shall my body lie dead in the field to feed crows than ever England shall pay one penny ransom for my body.

sp.speaker: Herald
sp.p: A kingly resolution.

sp.speaker: Henry V
sp.p:
No, herald, ’tis a kingly resolution and the resolution of a king. Here, take this for thy pains.
Henry V gives the Herald coins.
Exit Herald.
But stay, my lords. What time is it?

sp.speaker: All
sp.p: Prime, my lord.

sp.speaker: Henry V
sp.p: Then is it good time, no doubt, for all England prayeth for us. What, my lords, methinks you look cheerfully upon me? Why, then, with one voice and like true English hearts, with me throw up your caps and for England cry Saint George! — and God and Saint George help us!

div.stage: The Frenchmen cry within, Saint Denis, Saint Denis, Montjoy, Saint Denis! The Battle.
Enter King of England, and his Lords.

sp.speaker: Henry V
sp.p: Come, my lords, come. By this time our swords are almost drunk with French blood. But, my lords, which of you can tell me how many of our army be slain in the battle?

sp.speaker: Oxford
sp.p: An it please your majesty, there are of the French army slain above ten thousand twenty-six hundred, whereof are princes and nobles bearing banners. Besides, all the nobility of France are taken prisoners. Of your majesty’s army are slain none but the good duke of York and not above five or six and twenty common soldiers.

sp.speaker: Henry V
sp.p: For the good duke of York my uncle I am heartily sorry and greatly lament his misfortune, yet the honorable victory which the Lord hath given us doth make me much rejoice. But stay, here comes another French message.

div.stage: Sound trumpet. Enter a Herald and kneeleth.

sp.speaker: Herald
sp.p: God save the life of the most mighty conqueror, the honorable king of England.

sp.speaker: Henry V
sp.p: Now, herald, methinks the world is changed with you now. What, I am sure it is a great disgrace for a herald to kneel to the king of England. What is thy message?

sp.speaker: Herald
sp.p: My lord and master, the conquered king of France, sends thee long health with hearty greeting.

sp.speaker: Henry V
sp.p: Herald, his greetings are welcome, but I thank God for my health. Well, herald, say on.

sp.speaker: Herald
sp.p: He hath sent me to desire your majesty to give him leave to go into the field to view his poor countrymen, that they may all be honorably buried.

sp.speaker: Henry V
sp.p: Why, herald, doth thy lord and master send to me to bury the dead? Let him bury them, in God’s name. But I pray thee, herald, where is my lord high constable and those that would have had my ransom?

sp.speaker: Herald
sp.p: An it please your majesty, he was slain in the battle.

sp.speaker: Henry V
sp.p: Why, you may see, you will make yourselves sure before the victory be won. But, herald, what castle is this so near adjoining to our camp?

sp.speaker: Herald
sp.p: An it please your majesty, ’tis called the Castle of Agincourt.

sp.speaker: Henry V
sp.p: Well then, my lords of England, for the more honor of our Englishmen, I will that this be forever called the Battle of Agincourt.

sp.speaker: Herald
sp.p: An it please your majesty, I have a further message to deliver to your majesty.

sp.speaker: Henry V
sp.p: What is that, herald? Say on.

sp.speaker: Herald
sp.p: An it please your majesty, my lord and master craves to parley with your majesty.

sp.speaker: Henry V
sp.p: With a good will, so some of my nobles view the place, for fear of treachery and treason.

sp.speaker: Herald
sp.p: Your grace needs not to doubt that.

sp.speaker: Henry V
sp.p:
Well, tell him then, I will come.
Exit Herald.
Now, my lords, I will go into the field myself to view my countrymen and to have them honorably buried, for the French king shall never surpass me in courtesy while I am Harry king of England. Come on, my lords.

div.head: Scene 17 Video Sc. 17
div.stage: Enter John Cobbler, and Robin Pewterer.

sp.speaker: Robin
sp.p: Now, John Cobbler, didst thou see how the king did behave himself?

sp.speaker: John
sp.p: But, Robin, didst thou see what a policy the king had? To see how the Frenchmen were killed with the stakes of the trees!

sp.speaker: Robin
sp.p: Ay, John, there was a brave policy.

sp.speaker: English Soldier
sp.p: What are you, my masters?

sp.speaker: John and Robin
sp.p: Why, we be Englishmen.

sp.speaker: English Soldier
sp.p: Are you Englishmen? Then change your language, for the king’s tents are set afire, and all they that speak English will be killed.

sp.speaker: John
sp.p: What shall we do, Robin? Faith, I’ll shift, for I can speak broken French.

sp.speaker: Robin
sp.p: Faith, so can I. Let’s hear how thou canst speak.

sp.speaker: Robin
sp.p: That’s well. Come, let’s be gone.

div.stage: Enter Derrick roaming. After him a Frenchman, and takes him Derrick prisoner.

sp.speaker: Derrick
sp.p: O good Mounser.

sp.speaker: Frenchman
sp.p: Come, come, you vigliacco.

sp.speaker: Derrick
sp.p: Oh, I will, sir, I will.

sp.speaker: Frenchman
sp.p: Come quickly, you peasant.

sp.speaker: Derrick
sp.p: I will, sir. What shall I give you?

sp.speaker: Frenchman
sp.p: Marry, thou shalt give me one, two, tre, four hundred crowns.

sp.speaker: Derrick
sp.p: Nay, sir, I will give you more. I will give you as many crowns as will lie on your sword.

sp.speaker: Frenchman
sp.p: Wilt thou give me as many crowns as will lie on my sword?

sp.speaker: Derrick
sp.p: Ay, marry will I. Ay, but you must lay down your sword, or else they will not lie on your sword.

div.stage: Here the Frenchman lays down his sword, and the clown Derrick takes it up and hurls him down.

sp.speaker: Derrick
sp.p: Thou villain, darest thou look up?

sp.speaker: Frenchman
sp.p: O good Monsieur, comparteve. Monsieur, pardon me.

sp.speaker: Derrick
sp.p: O you villain, now you lie at my mercy, dost thou remember since thou lammst me in thy short ell? O villain, now I will strike off thy head.

div.stage: Here while he Derrick turns his back the Frenchman runs his ways.

sp.speaker: Derrick
sp.p: What, is he gone? Mass, I am glad of it, for if he had stayed I was afraid he would have stirred again, and then I should have been spilt. But I will away to kill more Frenchmen.

div.stage: Enter King of France, King of England, Secretary, and attendants.

sp.speaker: Henry V
sp.p: Now, my good brother of France, my coming into this land was not to shed blood but for the right of my country, which, if you can deny, I am content peaceably to leave my siege and to depart out of your land.

sp.speaker: Charles VI
sp.p: What is it you demand, my loving brother of England?

sp.speaker: Henry V
sp.p: My secretary hath it written. To Secretary Read it.

sp.speaker: Secretary
sp.p: Item, that immediately Henry of England be crowned king of France.

sp.speaker: Charles VI
sp.p: A very hard sentence, my good brother of England.

sp.speaker: Henry V
sp.p: No more but right, my good brother of France.

sp.speaker: Charles VI
sp.p: Well, read on.

sp.speaker: Secretary
sp.p: Item, that after the death of the said Henry, the crown remain to him and his heirs forever.

sp.speaker: Charles VI
sp.p: Why, then, you do not only mean to dispossess me but also my son.

sp.speaker: Henry V
sp.p: Why, my good brother of France, you have had it long enough, and, as for Prince Dauphin, it skills not though he sit beside the saddle. Thus I have set it down, and thus it shall be.

sp.speaker: Charles VI
sp.p: You are very peremptory, my good brother of England.

sp.speaker: Henry V
sp.p: And you as perverse, my good brother of France.

sp.speaker: Charles VI
sp.p: Why, then, belike all that I have here is yours.

sp.speaker: Henry V
sp.p: Ay, even as far as the kingdom of France reaches.

sp.speaker: Charles VI
sp.p: Ay, for by this hot beginning we shall scarce bring it to a calm ending.

sp.speaker: Henry V
sp.p: It is as you please. Here is my resolution.

sp.speaker: Charles VI
sp.p: Well, my brother of England, if you will give me a copy we will meet you again tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Henry V
sp.p:
With a good will, my good brother of France. Secretary, deliver him a copy.
Exit King of France, and all their attendants.
My lords of England, go before, and I will follow you.

sp.speaker: Henry V
sp.p:
Ah Harry, thrice-unhappy Harry! Hast thou now conquered the French king and begin’st a fresh supply with his daughter? But with what face canst thou seek to gain her love, which hath sought to win her father’s crown? Her father’s crown, said I? No, it is mine own. Ay, but I love her and must crave her. Nay, I love her and will have her.
Enter Lady Katherine and her Ladies.
But here she comes. How now, fair Lady Katherine of France, what news?

sp.speaker: Katherine
sp.p: An it please your majesty, my father sent me to know if you will debate any of these unreasonable demands which you require.

sp.speaker: Henry V
sp.p: Now trust me, Kate, I commend thy father’s wit greatly in this, for none in the world could sooner have made me debate it if it were possible. But tell me, sweet Kate, canst thou tell how to love?

sp.speaker: Katherine
sp.p: I cannot hate, my good lord, therefore far unfit were it for me to love.

sp.speaker: Henry V
sp.p: Tush, Kate. But tell me in plain terms, canst thou love the king of England? I cannot do as these countries do that spend half their time in wooing. Tush, wench, I am none such. But wilt thou go over to England?

sp.speaker: Katherine
sp.p: I would to God that I had your majesty as fast in love as you have my father in wars. I would not vouchsafe so much as one look until you had debated all these unreasonable demands.

sp.speaker: Henry V
sp.p: Tush, Kate, I know thou wouldst not use me so hardly. But tell me, canst thou love the king of England?

sp.speaker: Katherine
sp.p: How should I love him that hath dealt so hardly with my father?

sp.speaker: Henry V
sp.p: But I’ll deal as easily with thee as thy heart can imagine or tongue can require. How say’st thou? What will it be?

sp.speaker: Katherine
sp.p: If I were of my own direction, I could give you answer. But seeing I stand at my father’s direction, I must first know his will.

sp.speaker: Henry V
sp.p: But shall I have thy good will in the mean season?

sp.speaker: Katherine
sp.p: Whereas I can put your grace in no assurance, I would be loath to put you in any despair.

sp.speaker: Henry V
sp.p: Now before God, it is a sweet wench.

div.stage: She goes aside, and speaks as followeth.

sp.speaker: Katherine
sp.p: I may think myself the happiest in the world, that is beloved of the mighty king of England.

sp.speaker: Henry V
sp.p: Well, Kate, are you at host with me? Sweet Kate, tell thy father from me that none in the world could sooner have persuaded me to it than thou, and so tell thy father from me.

sp.speaker: Katherine
sp.p: God keep your majesty in good health.

div.stage: Exit Katherine of France and her Ladies.

sp.speaker: Henry V
sp.p: Farewell, sweet Kate! In faith, it is a sweet wench, but, if I knew I could not have her father’s good will, I would so rouse the towers over his ears that I would make him be glad to bring her me upon his hands and knees.

div.stage: Enter Derrick, with his girdle full of shoes.

sp.speaker: Derrick
sp.p: How now? Zounds, it did me good to see how I did triumph over the Frenchmen.

div.stage: Enter John Cobbler roving, with a pack full of apparel.

sp.speaker: John
sp.p: Whoop, Derick! How dost thou?

sp.speaker: Derrick
sp.p: What, John! Comedevales! Alive yet?

sp.speaker: John
sp.p: I promise thee, Derrick, I scaped hardly, for I was within half a mile when one was killed.

sp.speaker: Derrick
sp.p: Were you so?

sp.speaker: John
sp.p: Ay, trust me, I had like been slain.

sp.speaker: Derrick
sp.p: But once killed, why, it is nothing! I was four or five times slain.

sp.speaker: John
sp.p: Four or five times slain! Why, how couldst thou have been alive now?

sp.speaker: Derrick
sp.p: Oh, John, never say so, for I was called the bloody soldier amongst them all.

sp.speaker: John
sp.p: Why, what didst thou?

sp.speaker: Derrick
sp.p: Why, I will tell thee, John. Every day when I went into the field I would take a straw and thrust it into my nose and make my nose bleed, and then I would go into the field, and when the captain saw me he would say, Peace, a bloody soldier, and bid me stand aside, whereof I was glad. But mark the chance, John. I went and stood behind a tree — but mark then, John. I thought I had been safe, but on a sudden there steps to me a lusty tall Frenchman. Now he drew, and I drew. Now I lay here, and he lay there. Now I set this leg before, and turned this backward, and skipped quite over a hedge, and he saw me no more there that day. And was not this well done, John?

sp.speaker: John
sp.p: Mass, Derick, thou hast a witty head.

sp.speaker: Derrick
sp.p: Ay, John, thou mayst see, if thou hadst taken my counsel — but what hast thou there? I think thou hast been robbing the Frenchmen.

sp.speaker: John
sp.p: Ay, faith, Derrick, I have gotten some reparel to carry home to my wife.

sp.speaker: Derrick
sp.p: And I have got some shoes, for I’ll tell thee what I did. When they were dead, I would go take off all their shoes.

sp.speaker: John
sp.p: Ay, but Derrick, how shall we get home?

sp.speaker: Derrick
sp.p: Nay, zounds, an they take thee they will hang thee. O John, never do so. If it be thy fortune to be hanged, be hanged in thy own language whatsoever thou dost.

sp.speaker: John
sp.p: Why, Derrick, the wars is done. We may go home now.

sp.speaker: Derrick
sp.p: Ay, but you may not go before you ask the king leave. But I know a way to go home and ask the king no leave.

sp.speaker: John
sp.p: How is that, Derrick?

sp.speaker: Derrick
sp.p: Why, John, thou knowest the duke of York’s funeral must be carried into England, dost thou not?

sp.speaker: John
sp.p: Ay, that I do.
